missing_information: Total gross income received from all side jobs.
Nature and total amount of any expenses incurred related to the handyman work.
Whether the activity was engaged in for profit (business) or not (hobby).
If any Forms 1099-NEC or 1099-K were received for this work.
Whether any estimated tax payments were made during the year for this income.
interview_questions: Could you provide an estimate of the total cash payments you received for the handyman work throughout the year?
Did you keep records of any expenses related to these side jobs, such as materials, tools, or mileage?
Were you aiming to make a profit from this handyman work, or was it more occasional?
Did you receive any tax forms, like a 1099-NEC or 1099-K, from the individuals or companies you did this work for?
Did you make any quarterly estimated tax payments to the IRS or state related to this additional income?
documentation_needed: Log or summary of cash income received.
Receipts or records for any related expenses.
Any Forms 1099-NEC or 1099-K received.
Records of any estimated tax payments made.

missing_information: Amount of health insurance premiums paid (including Medicare Part B and any other private insurance).
Confirmation of whether any medical expenses were reimbursed by insurance or paid through tax-advantaged accounts (HSA, FSA).
Details about health insurance coverage type (e.g., employer-sponsored, marketplace, Medicare).
Confirmation that the expenses claimed were not for cosmetic surgery or general health items.
Total AGI to confirm if the 7.5% threshold for medical expense deductions is met (AGI is provided, but confirmation needed).
interview_questions: How much did you pay in premiums for your Medicare Part B coverage last year? This is often shown on your Social Security statement (SSA-1099).
Did you have any other health insurance coverage during the year, and if so, how much did you pay in premiums for it?
Were any of the medical expenses you provided receipts for reimbursed by your insurance company?
Did you use funds from a Health Savings Account (HSA) or Flexible Spending Account (FSA) to pay for any of these medical costs?
Can you confirm these medical expenses were for diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease, and not for purely cosmetic reasons?
documentation_needed: Form SSA-1099 (showing Medicare Part B premiums withheld).
Form 1095-A, B, or C (proof of health coverage).
Proof of payment for any additional health insurance premiums.
Explanation of Benefits (EOBs) from insurance showing reimbursements.
Statements for any HSA/FSA accounts used.

missing_information: Exact number of nights Tyler lived with the client during the tax year.
Confirmation that Tyler did not provide more than half of his own support for the year.
Tyler's gross income for the tax year (if any).
Confirmation of Tyler's full-time student status (enrolled full-time for at least 5 months of the year).
Details from the divorce decree regarding which parent is entitled to claim the child as a dependent.
interview_questions: Can you tell me the specific dates or number of nights Tyler lived in your home during the tax year?
Did Tyler have a job or receive any income during the year? If so, approximately how much did he earn?
Considering all sources, did Tyler provide more than half of his own financial support (covering costs like housing, food, education, etc.)?
Was Tyler enrolled as a full-time student at the university for at least five months during the calendar year?
Does your divorce decree specify which parent has the right to claim Tyler as a dependent for tax purposes?
documentation_needed: Form 1098-T (Tuition Statement) from the university.
School enrollment verification confirming full-time status for at least 5 months.
Divorce decree or Form 8332 (Release/Revocation of Release of Claim to Exemption for Child by Custodial Parent) if applicable.
Records/receipts demonstrating client provided more than 50% of Tyler's support (if needed).
Information on Tyler's income (pay stubs, W-2 if applicable).

missing_information: Confirmation whether working from home was a requirement for the convenience of the employer, not just the employee's choice.
Written documentation from the employer confirming the work-from-home requirement.
Square footage of the dedicated home office space and the total square footage of the home.
Confirmation that the home office space is used exclusively and regularly for business.
Details on employer reimbursement policy for home office expenses.
interview_questions: Was working from home mandated by your employer as a condition of your employment, or was it offered as an option for your convenience?
Do you have any written communication or policy document from your employer stating that you are required to maintain a home office?
What is the approximate square footage of the room or area used exclusively for your work, and what is the total square footage of your home?
Can you confirm that this space in your home is used only for your work activities and not for personal purposes?
Does your employer reimburse you for any home office expenses, such as internet, supplies, or equipment?
scenarios.tax_form: Form 8829 / Form 1040 Schedule C (if self-employed) or State Tax Return (if applicable); Generally N/A for Federal W-2 employees post-TCJA
documentation_needed: Written statement from employer confirming WFH requirement for their convenience.
Measurements of home office space and total home square footage.
Receipts for direct home office expenses (desk, chair, monitor, supplies).
Utility bills (if claiming indirect expenses, though less common for employees).
Employer reimbursement policy documentation.

missing_information: Proper qualified written acknowledgment for the Children's Hospital donation (must include tax ID, date, amount, and statement regarding goods/services received).
Detailed description of the donated furniture (e.g., sofa, table, chairs), including their condition at the time of donation.
Method used to determine the Fair Market Value (FMV) of the donated furniture ($2,000).
A properly completed written acknowledgment from Goodwill for the non-cash donation over $250, meeting IRS requirements.
Confirmation that no substantial goods or services were received in return for any of the donations.
interview_questions: Do you have a formal acknowledgment letter from the Children's Hospital that includes their tax ID number and confirms you received no goods or services in return for your donation?
For the furniture donated to Goodwill, can you provide a list describing each item (e.g., 'Leather Sofa', 'Oak Dining Table') and its condition (e.g., 'Good', 'Fair') when you donated it?
How did you arrive at the $2,000 value for the donated furniture? Did you use thrift shop values or another method?
The handwritten receipt from Goodwill might not be sufficient. Do you have a more formal acknowledgment from them that meets IRS requirements for donations over $250?
For all your donations, can you confirm that you didn't receive anything of significant value (like event tickets, merchandise, etc.) in return?
documentation_needed: Qualified written acknowledgments from each charity for cash donations of $250 or more.
Bank records or canceled checks for cash donations under $250.
Detailed list and description (including condition) of non-cash items donated.
Qualified written acknowledgment from Goodwill for non-cash donation (meeting IRS requirements).
Form 8283 (Noncash Charitable Contributions) if total non-cash donations exceed $500.
